...under all my saddles and boots, I'm a woman who likes to slip out at night...

"Weird Al" Yankovic did a song about becoming constipated, caring on a romance with his cousin and then getting his head chopped off on a rollercoaster.
 
 This does not mean that he is actually becoming constipated
 This does not mean that he is into his cousin
 This does not me that he really got his head chopped off.
 
 Yes, I know, someone is going to say that "Weird Al" doesn't count. Well fine then.
 
 Tom Petty (and the Heartbreakers) sang "Mary Jane's Last Dance" about Marajuana. This does not mean for a fact that he was using it. (Did he or didn't he, that's not what he was singing about.)
 
 In the song "Into The Fire," by Bruce Springsteen on The Rising album, he sings "I need your kiss, but love and duty call you someplace higer, up the stairs, into the fire." This does not mean that he's into kissing firemen.
 
 In Bob Seger and the Silver Bullet Band's "The Fire Inside," he's singing about a one night stand with the last part of the song being about the point a view of the woman. "Now the hour is late and he thinks you're asleep. You listen to him dress and you listen to him leave like you know he would. You hear his car pull away in the street then you move to the door and you lock it when he's gone for good." This does not mean that he dresses up like a woman and goes and has one night stands.

 Just so you'll know...I worship Willie Nelson...have for some time...probably since before some of you were born. I posted the question after it was a blurb in the morning news (TV) a few days ago. I hadn't heard the song then and haven't heard it yet. I doubt that singing about gay cowboys makes the singer gay anyway. I can't imagine that Willie is...yet it wouldn't matter if he is.
 
 This (speaking of me) is a man who got drunk in 1980 and called the Willie Nelson Country Club to ask him to sing at my wedding. This is a man who told two yuppies to shut the **** up in the middle of Willie Nelson concert at Chastain Park. (They were sitting next to me and my daughter, talking incessantly about whether they'd rather live in Atlanta or San Francisco. She went to buy some tee-shirts and I told the most talkative one that I came to listen to God play and sing and that I didn't give a **** *** where either of them wanted to live.) This is a man who memorized "The Red-Headed Stranger" and dozens of other songs Willie did.
 
 My heroes have always been cowboys. They still are, it seems.
